title: About
text:
The Joyful Pursuit of Rocky Knowledge
My journey took an exciting turn with the opportunity to explore geology in Puerto Rico. Imagine a classroom where every rock formation is a live textbook on natural history! This experience has enriched my skills and prepared me to share this blend of knowledge and wonder with others, from eager students to seasoned scientists.

title: Awards and Honors
text:
- Quaternary Geology and Geomorphology (QG&G) Division of the Geological Society of America’s Donald R. Coates Award for 2023 for my research proposal: Uncovering the Drivers of Mountain Relief in the Granodiorite and Volcaniclastic Bedrock of Puerto Rico.
-National Science Foundation’s Bridge to the Doctorate Fellowship for Master’s Completion at Boise State University.
- Diversity Participation Award at the IALE-NA Conference.
- NSF Grant: EAGER Collaborative Research Board Member.
- Pacific Northwest LSAMP Conference Panelist.
- New Mexico Homegrown Scientist’s Panelist.
- Alliance for Minority Participation Recipient.
- Geological Society of America’s J. David Lowell Field Camp Scholarship.
- Excellence in Undergraduate Student Research Awards, UNM.
- Stuart A. Northrop Award, UNM.
- Leonard Research Fellowship.
- Leadership & Involvement Award, UNM.
- AWG Sand Student Research Presentation Travel Award.
- STEAM Honorary Participant, Dream Builders Workshop.

title: Rocking Geoscience
text:
At Colorado State University (CSU), I’ve embarked on an exhilarating journey into Geoscience for my Doctorate. It’s a realm where mountains perform their slow-motion rise, landscapes evolve like dynamic masterpieces, and bedrock rivers tell tales of ancient flows. This fascinating interplay of natural forces has captivated me!
The Geoscience department at CSU isn’t just about lectures and labs; it’s a playground for budding earth detectives like me. Every day is an opportunity to unravel the mysteries of mountain building, landscape evolution, and bedrock river analysis. And in this serious world of science, amidst the rigorous research and intense study sessions, there’s always room for a good laugh, especially when rocks decide to play hide and seek during fieldwork.
